title: Match Selects President Of Zynga as Its Next CEO
text:
The switch comes as Match continues to deal with the ebbs and flows of the continuing Covid-19 pandemic, as outbreaks, lockdowns and reopenings have affected dating trends and users' willingness to pay for subscriptions to company's apps that include its eponymous brand, as well as OkCupid and Hinge.

"The endless waves of Covid have impacted word-of-mouth virality and new user adoption of our services," the company said in a letter to shareholders on Tuesday detailing its first-quarter results.

It added that the company is preparing marketing campaigns to encourage people to socialize and meet more regularly to attract new users.

Ms. Dubey, 51 years old, will continue to serve as a director on Match's board and will also serve as a company adviser. She took over as CEO in March 2020 following the departure of Mandy Ginsberg, who left for personal reasons.

Ms. Dubey joined Match in 2006, with prior stints ranging from serving as Match's president to chief operating officer of online dating platform Tinder.

Ms. Dubey said stepping away from day-to-day management will give her time "to focus on what is hopefully the 'give back' chapter of my life."

Mr. Kim, 45, has served as Zynga's president since 2016 and oversaw areas ranging from user acquisition, product management and mergers and acquisitions.

He is leaving Zynga, best known for mobile game apps "Words With Friends" and "FarmVille," while a deal with Take-Two Interactive Software Inc. is pending.

The videogame company in January agreed to buy the mobile-game publisher in a roughly $11 billion deal, which is expected to close by midyear.

The deal came in the same month that other blockbuster deals were announced. Microsoft Corp. agreed to buy Activision Blizzard Inc. in an all-cash deal valued at about $75 billion. Not long after that, Sony Group Corp.'s videogame unit said it is buying videogame developer Bungie Inc. in a deal valued at $3.6 billion.

For the first quarter, Match's revenue of $798.6 million exceeded analysts' expectations of $794.1 million. Total paying users reached 16.3 million, in line with analysts' expectations.

For the second quarter, the company projected revenue of $800 million to $810 million. Analysts were expecting $835.6 million.

The company said its revenue forecast included hits from foreign exchange and the effects of the war in Ukraine.

Shares of the company fell roughly 4.7% in after-hours trading.

The stock closed Tuesday at $79.02, down 2.1%. It is down nearly 47% over the past 12 months.

The company also said its board authorized a buyback for 12.5 million of its shares outstanding.
